headline.main: Japan and Tobacco Revenue: Leader Faces Difficult Choice

docs.abstract: Issue of smoking presents fledgling government of Japanese Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi with hard choice of giving teeth to country's weak anti-smoking programs or sacrificing health to urgent need for tax revenues from sale of cigarettes; delicate situation is illustrated by Mayor Takayoshi Hirasawa's rejection of World Health Organization award for banning cigarette vending machines in his small town north of Tokyo; powerful industry is fighting law, first ever in country where cigarette vending machines are as common as water fountains; photo; graph; anti-smoking groups are heartened by fact that prime minister himself stopped smoking twenty years ago, bans ashtrays from cabinet rooms and, as health minister in 1997, pushed through white paper on health implications of smoking over strong objections of powerful Finance Ministry, which has vetoed even most timid attempts to raise public awareness (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: For pushing through an ordinance banning cigarette vending machines from the streets of his tiny town a few hundred miles north of Tokyo, the World Health Organization wanted to bestow an award on the mayor of Fukauramachi in honor of No Smoking Day last month. But the mayor refused it. The law, the first in a country where cigarette vending machines are as common as water fountains, does not take effect until Oct. 1 and includes no penalties for violators -- but some vending machine owners are still fighting it.
